whatIsService.title: What Is Skin Pigmentation (Melasma)?
whatIsService.content:
Often seen as dark patches or uneven tone skin pigmentation occurs when the skin produces excess melanin. One of the most common forms is melasma, which typically appears as brown or grey-brown patches on the face, especially the cheeks, forehead, nose, or upper lip. While pigmentation and melasma are not harmful, they can deeply affect confidence and make skin look uneven or aged.

At The Skin Firm, we specialise in advanced pigmentation and melasma treatments that go beyond covering up the patches we target the root causes to restore clear, even-toned, radiant skin.

signsSymptoms.title: Signs & Symptoms of Pigmentation & Melasma
items: Brown, grey, or tan patches on the face
Uneven skin tone or blotchy appearance
Pigmentation on cheeks, forehead, or upper lip
Stubborn marks that worsen with heat or hormones
Skin that looks aged or dull due to uneven tone

faqs.title: FAQs on Pigmentation Treatment in Pune

questions.question: How soon will I see results from the pigmentation treatment?
questions.answer: Most clients notice visible improvement within 4–6 sessions, depending on pigmentation severity and skin type. For enduring results, maintaining a long-term regimen is essential.

questions.question: Is this treatment suitable for melasma?
questions.answer: Yes. Our protocol is specifically designed to treat melasma and other forms of pigmentation. The treatment is customised after a thorough skin evaluation.

questions.question: Can sensitive skin tolerate these procedures?
questions.answer: Absolutely. We carefully select our treatments and products, ensuring they're effective yet gentle. Sensitive skin types are treated with additional care.

questions.question: Will the pigmentation come back?
questions.answer: With proper maintenance and sun protection, results are long-lasting. However, new pigmentation can develop with sun exposure or hormonal changes.

questions.question: How often should I get the treatment done?
questions.answer: Typically, sessions are spaced 2–4 weeks apart. Your dermatologist will create a schedule based on your skin's needs and response.
